They're shy kids who have trouble verbalizing their feelings to others. They get anxious easily. Koutarou is normally reserved but with people he's close with like his friends he can be pretty lively, whereas Akane is shy around her friends as well. I could write more but that's the basic of it. I don't understand your assumption that they have 'no personality,' seems like you're either not paying attention or you have some weird idea of what constitutes a personality.

WRITING.TITLE: Your thoughts on A Clockwork Orange?
WRITING.TEXT:
I read it recently and watched the movie after that. What do you think of it? Do you think it's better with or without the final chapter?
For me, the most interesting aspect was probably the slang, if you guys know of any books that do something similar, feel free to recommend them to me. Also, I feel like this is probably controversial but personally I disagree with the view that a person should be given free will when they're clearly exercising that free will to ruin other people's lives. Though, I guess this leads to the slippery slope that everyone causes some level of harm to others, but the level of harm is far apart.
Also, I don't know if Burgess intended this or maybe I'm just misinterpreting something, but the last chapter made me think about something. The whole book is about Alex being controlled by others, but at the end, he's controlled by his own subconscious desires. He wants a baby because his subconscious mind desires it and he can't find pleasure in ultraviolence anymore. Isn't that a bit similar to what the government was doing to him with the Ludovico Technique, except, instead of pain and sickness, it's a more deeper unhappiness. We're controlled by our subconscious whether we like it or not.
Code Geass, Natsume Yuujinchuu, Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon, Kuzu no Honkai, Mob Psycho 100 and Shirobako.
Mayaka Chitanda
Thanks!
Ah, I see, thanks!

I think you might like Kaiba. It's pretty different from the Divergent type dystopias you see in YA. It's about a world where memories can be stored in chips and transferred from body to body.
I think the anime improves on the manga a lot, even in the first season, I felt it was way better.

Adding on to DocRocksO's list, from what I've seen of stuff by Kyoto Animation, they seem to employ show don't tell pretty well too. And Shouwa Genroku Rakugo Shinjuu and the currently airing Tsuki ga Kirei has a lot that as well. Also, he mentions Miyazaki specifically but from what I've seen Studio Ghibli's stuff in general is better in regards to this than the vast majority of anime. There's also several anime which have badly written exposition as well as great visual storytelling such as Mob Psycho 100 and Evangelion and 3-Gatsu no Lion (which doesn't really have much blatant exposition but there's a few scenes where I felt dialogue was pointlessly reiterating stuff unnaturally).
I think it might be because a lot of anime are made as cheap, easy to consume entertainment and the main audience would rather watch something that spoonfeeds them information rather than having it naturally come out through the story.

About the tension aspect, I don't think there was supposed to be. It's supposed to be a conclusion to Shinji's character arc. It's also supposed to be isolated from the rest of the show, it's taking place during Instrumentality after all.
About skipping out on what happened, I sort of agree, but I don't mind it either. The series was never about the actual fights, it was about the impact they had on the characters and with the culmination of that, we skip the fun bits entirely and focus on the characters.

I loved Hyouka more and more with each passing episode. I kept thinking about various aspects of it a lot after I finished and a month or two after that, I rewatched it, and confirmed just how much I loved it.
Kaiba is not exactly post-apocalyptic but it's dystopian. It's dark and twisted, but in a different way from Attack on Titan.
Yeah, to be honest, I like these more than EoE as well. It resolves the main thematic conflict in the show, and so does EoE but personally I prefer the way they do it here.

Most fans seem to really dislike these episodes and prefer EoE. Personally, I think they work together. These dive into the minds of what the characters were experiencing while going through instrumentality while the movie focuses on the actual events surrounding Instrumentality. I know the movie has those elements too, but it handles them differently enough that I feel like these two episodes are worth the watch.

While I love Viral's alternate reality, I don't get what exactly the alternate realities were supposed to represent. For Viral, it was a dream that would never come true, and for the other minor characters, it seems to be similar; it's something that they want. But foe Simon and Yoko, it's different. Simon is in a reality with a much more cowardly Kamina and Yoko's is kinda random, though all the possibilities show her as satisfied in life.
Yeah, OPM, had surprisingly good emotional moments for a parody series.

Hyouka has a lot of great visual storytelling. If you guys haven't read them, you should read wrongeverytime's posts on his website that talk about some of the techniques used in each episode. I suspect a large reason why fans of Hyouka like it so much is because of its visual storytelling.

That they're all sexually exploitative towards women. I stumbled upon a reddit thread where someone asked women how they felt about the sexualisation of women in anime. There was one good answer talking about how there's tons of shows that don't have that kind of stuff and that the stereotype is more prevalent than the actual sexualisation in anime. The other answers were all, "I dislike it and that's why I don't watch anime. Miyazaki is one of the few exceptions that doesn't have this." There was even a reply claiming that Miyazaki movies were the sole exceptions to this rule. Not even all of Ghibli's movies, *just* Miyazaki. Ignorant people irritate me to no end.
The mangaka who wrote the source material for Tekkon Kinkreet also wrote the manga that Ping Pong is based on, that's why the style's so similar.

I think that only applies to plot points or character archetypes. With your argument, you could even claim that using camera angles to show a character's emotions or status is a cliche because it's been done to death. It's not a plot point, it's a representation of an emotion that the viewer can easily understand.

It's part of the symbolic language of anime, it shows an emotion or intent through easily understood symbols, it isn't a crutch, it's a way of quickly showing emotion.

if you think cyberpunk is "generic sci-fi" then I have several dozen "we're in space and something goes wrong" movies to show you. Cyberpunk settings rarely show up in full feature films.
Setting alone is not what makes a movie generic. Plot structure, tropes, pacing, characters and script are far more important.

I wouldn't go so far as to say that it's the movie he's been trying to make his entire career. It does revolve around themes that he likes basing his work around but the writing is different. His older works were different tonally. They were more melancholy and mellow and had less comedy.

For, the most part, yeah. The colouring in a lot of older series wasn't much different, but it didn't look too bad, but add the digital crispness and it looks ugly. There's still lots of shows with great colouring and shows that do make great use of digital effects work, though. As for HxH, yeah, it looks so ugly, I've seen clips of it and it looks so computerized and shiny. I've seen stills of the older series that looks really good. If the storytelling is just as good in the first, then I'd rather just watch that version.
That's still hand-drawn though :P And not all animators work digitally, lots of animators still work on paper. I'm not completely sure on this but I think the majority still uses paper.

That doesn't mean they aren't hand-drawn, though. The drawing is done by hand, some animators do it on paper, others on a computer using a tablet. Colouring and digital effects are all done on computer though. And a lot of early 2000s anime had thaqt look as well IIRC since digital technology was new and everyone wanted to use it without knowing how. I don't like the glossy look too much either but if done right it does look good.

when things were still hand drawn that is.
They still are.
It's an adaptation of the manga.
As someone who likes Shinkai's older movies more than this one, what shortcomings do you mean?

As a fan of the creator's other works, this is somewhat different. For one thing, it's more narrative focused than 5 cm or Garden of Words but it is kind of a sentimental melodrama. Imo, it uses some really hamfisted ways to make you feel sad and there's some plotholes but it's a worthwhile rom-com and not as full of pathos as Shinkai's other work.

If you guys like this movie, you should check out Makoto Shinkai's other movies. 5 cm Per Second is my favorite adn it's also his most well-received movie (it's not as well known as Your Name though).
Your Name has some similarities with his previous work, mostly thematically and visually but it is a bit different from other movies I've seen by him, it's more mainstream, I guess you could say. Not to say that's bad, but his other stuff tends to be more mood-focused than character or story focused.

Well, this was a disappointing.
The world is actually pretty cool but the writing and the visuals are shit. The animators can't draw, the animation in the fight scene was shit and the colouring is ugly in a bunch of scenes. The music doesn't sound right either, like in the scene where they talk about the military's plans to let Kyoto get destroyed, it doesn't fit at all, it sounds like generic music from a video game.

Wait, really? I'm kinda surprised hearing this because when I first got into anime, if a series had an English dub, I'd just watch that. The Eva dub is what changed me into watching subbed shows only.

I didn't really enjoy Eva the first time I watched it but I really loved the visuals and took a bunch of screenshots this time around that I was planning on posting here as an imgur album but didn't cause it breaks the illegal content rule (watermarks).
I really like the use of flat silhouettes in some of the shots. The backgrounds showing the city in the opening scenes are pretty neat, the buildings are very lightly done (I can't come up with the words to describe it) they're pale grey looking and not very detailed which adds to the atmosphere in a way that I can't describe (again). This show's visuals are great though, both in their shot composition and framing and its use of colour. I really like the shot of Gendo and Shinji's first meeting, with Gendo in a tiny window of yellow light in the upper corner, far out of Shinji's reach and Unit 1's horn thing connecting him and Shinji. I was pretty dissapointed in the first Rebuild because it was a lot more generic (imo even kinda ugly) in terms of its visuals.
Maybe they could loosely tie the skits together, or maybe improve or add to them like Nichijou
the transition cuts were rough Can you explain why you think that? I didn't notice anything that bad in the editing.

Well, that was shit. The colouring is bland, the character designs are generic and I don't like the art style, the animation is kinda meh and the story seems generic. There was literally nothing about this episode that got me hooked.

Sure, that's true but for shows that have long running source material, the 1 cour first season tends to be them testing the waters to see if it's profitable and then next season it's longer, like with Boku no Hero Academia.

I'm pretty sure his smelling power was used in the first season as well, in the woods when the female titan screamed and all the other titans rushed toward her. He smelled that titans were coming. He also sniffed Eren before the trial scene.
How can you still say that after all the plot armor in the first season lol

I don't remember much about how this arc began in the manga but I remember it being different, so anyone who does remember, how faithful is it?
I like the additional scene with Eren and Mikasa but something about the direction in this episode felt off. I read here that Tetsuro Araki didn't direct this season, and if that's true, then it makes sense. It doesn't capture the scale of the terror that well when the titans appear, especially during the Beast Titan's appearance and the music playing during Mike's battle didn't feel right, the fight itself was kinda underwhelming and didn't really show his skill properly.
The OP was pretty disappointing sound-wise, but it has some cool visuals (what's up with the animals though) and the ED has some nice foreshadowing and it sounds kind of creepy but I still like both the EDs from the first season way more.
Some weird directing techniques though, not a fan of the whole rewind thing they did and they did this weird rapid cut thing while Mike was getting eaten that was similar to Eren's dream at the beginning of the first season. Didn't really like that either.
The visual quality of the show seems to have increased, there's less drawing errors this time around than there were in the first season and the thick outlines are toned back a bit.
Disappointing in some aspects, great in others. The first season was better than the manga so let's hope this one continues that trend.

What if it's anime original such as Flip Flappers, or if the pacing fits the show better as a 12 ep series? Not everything needs to be over 20+ eps, it can just feel bloated, just look at Attack on Titan, the second half is way too slow (mostly because the manga's pacing is bad but you get the point.) You need to pace your shows properly, some shows work better as 11-12 episode series, others do better as 20+ episodes. Tatami Galaxy and Ping Pong, for example, are paced perfectly as 11 ep series. The amount of source material released isn't and shouldn't be the only aspect to look into when figuring out the pacing for a show.
I don't remember seeing much about art being underpaid on /ic/, just that it's hard to get into cause you need contacts.
Nah, different shows need different paces, some shows would be way too stretched out if they were 20+ episodes.

In real life, most people would probably think she has some kind of mental issues, aside from the fact that she has no sense of personal space, she behaves pretty childishly throughout the show. Don't get me wrong, I like the show but if you saw anyone like her in real life you'd be pretty weirded out. Unrealistic characters aren't necessarily bad characters though.
ACCA and Kuzu no Honkai have pretty great EDs, as for OPs the only one I really like is Kuzu no Honkai but Maid Dragon's grew on me over time.
Slice of life and iyashikei and the use of internal monologues. Also characters that aren't realistic in any way (eg: Chitanda from Hyouka)

That's not why animation is sparse. Character complexity was born out of people moving away from Tezuka-esque styles, anime has a low budget and animators are paid per drawing, so less drawings = less budget wasted.

There's other shows that were good at first but declined in quality and others that didn't get me all hyped at the beginning but got better later on but these are the ones I've enjoyed all the way through.

I really like Natsume from Natsume Yuujinchou and to a lesser extent Wolfgang Grimmer from Monster, they've both had a shitty past (Grimmer especially) and I can relate to Natsume being an outcast but they're both pretty selfless people, even though Grimmer [Monster](/s "can't even feel emotions like sadness or guilt.") While I do relate to Oreki in hiding insecurities through lying, I found his whole thing about his life motto and energy conservation to be kind of annoying, honestly. I like relatable characters, I liked Shinji from NGE (but not in EoE) but I don't like Oreki thaat much, especially toward the beginning, because I found him irritating.
I think Hyouka's ending is great, but it's still possible to build it further and do it well. The novels are still going so maybe there might be a second season.

The reason we associate short blue hair or flamey red hair with those two character archetypes is because of EVA I think, not necessarily the other way around. Nope, it's basic colour theory. Red: fiery, Blue: cool (The different hues also play a part in it)

I think Mikasa does have romantic feelings for Eren but even it's just familial love, it still makes sense, Eren risked his life to save her and was the first person to show her affection after the death of he family and he never treats her differently than he would any other friend/family member.
So they traced over CG? Because the wonkiness of the shapes doesn't look like it's CG.
There's two more big mysteries and the last five episodes are all episodic. The overarching plot is about Oreki coming out of his shell, and the final episode pays of pretty well.

I don't think that it's Mimi at the top. The colours aren't really true to the show, Papika's hair is peach rather orange/red. Plus, aside from being a reference to Hansel and Gretel I feel it sort of reflects what happens in the show, [Flip Flappers spoilers](/s "she keeps Papika trapped and sort of holds Cocona hostage")
I haven't seen Penny Dreadful but saying a show should only focus on a good actor if they cast a good actor is a dumb reason for saying a show is bad.

We got to see Levi be badass, that was a fun scene. He seems unaffected by the death of his soldier, but he's still willing to get covered in blood to comfort him in his last moments. Also love the scene in the Titan's belly, it's the perfect amount of cheesy and Vogel im Kafig may be my favorite song in this series aside from the OP and EDs.
Armin and Mikasa are willing to put their lives in danger to protect Eren, even when everyone else thinks he's a monster (which he is). It really shows the bond between them better than any monologue would.

Adding on to otaku34's comment, he also has a movie coming up called [Yoru wa Mijikashi Arukeyo Otome](https://myanimelist.net/anime/34537/Yoru_wa_Mijikashi_Arukeyo_Otome?q=yoru%20wa%20mij) with a visual style really similar to Tatami Galaxy and the writer of the source material also wrote the novel that Tatami Galaxy is based on. In terms of art style, his other work isn't really similar to Tatami Galaxy as he likes to experiment with styles but they're all still worth checking out.

If you like moe comedies, then K-On, if you like drama, then Hibike Euphonium and if you like slow slice of lifes and detective fiction then Hyouka.
You can't really judge an entire studio's work based on one series by them, even if they rely on similar settings in most of them, they have different tones.
Caught up with you guys, I forgot how much I used to enjoy this series, I love the scene where Eren emerges and Mikasa runs to him crying.

Holden's suffered through some shitty things and he's generally lost and feels cut off from the rest of society, thinking that no one understands how he feels. I think a lot of people around his age can relate to his feelings (aside from the trauma).
If you want something that doesn't look at all like a typical anime and can be kinda fucked up at times, then Kaiba.

I like most things about Hyouka but I especially love the silly visual metaphors. I dislike Monster because of how melodramatic it can be and some of the dialogue, I remember thinking sounded pretentious. And I dislike Kuzu no Honkai because the character's decisions only exist to further the drama.

I saw Ghost in the Shell recently and it still holds up pretty well. It's not consistently amazing but it's pretty good. From what I've seen of Akira it looks pretty gorgeous as well. Also, I don't think Makoto Shinkai movies really have good animation though. The backgrounds are what they look the best at and the animation is kinda dull and at times mechanical looking.

Pretty much anything by KyoAni (esp. Hibike, Hyouka, Nichijou and maybe K-On) and also, I think Mob Psycho 100 as well. Masaaki Yuasa works generally tend to have good animation as well, I think Kaiba and Tatami Galaxy have consistently good animation. Ping Pong's isn't bad either but it's not as consistent as the other two.

It's definitely not a bad episode by any means, I don't think Hyouka has any (even 11.5, which alot of people seem to dislike) but I personally found it a bit underwhelming compared to the other episodes.
